Legal_Issue: Whether the transitional provisions of the Immigration Act amendments violate s. 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms by eliminating the right to appeal
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 7
Application_Facts: The applicant's appeal was converted to a judicial review under new provisions of the Immigration Act
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; transitional provisions upheld as constitutional
Court_Ruling: The transitional provisions do not infringe on s. 7 rights
Grounds_for_Claim: Elimination of the right to appeal under the transitional provisions
Legal_Standard: Section 7 of the Charter protects life, liberty, and security of the person in accordance with principles of fundamental justice
Procedural_Issue: Conversion of appeal to judicial review
Review_Standard: Judicial review analyzed for compliance with s. 7 of the Charter
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Basis: Principles of fundamental justice, including procedural fairness
Governing_Rule: Section 7 does not guarantee a statutory right to appeal; judicial review suffices for fundamental justice
Cause_Description: Amendments to the Immigration Act altered appeal procedures for refugee claimants
Legal_Provision_Violated: Alleged violation of s. 7 of the Charter
Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Decision_Rationale: Judicial review adequately protects s. 7 rights by ensuring procedural fairness
Legal_Standard_Applied: Principles of fundamental justice under s. 7
